Last week in Congress, legislation I cosponsored to protect Americans' email privacy passed in the House. H.R.387, the Email Privacy Act, updates the Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA) to improve privacy protections for electronic communications stored or maintained by a third-party service provider. It also requires the government to obtain a search warrant from a court in criminal investigations before a provider is required to disclose the content of communications, while not impeding law enforcement’s efforts to protect the public. You can read more about this legislation here: https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/387?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22hr387%22%5D%7D&r=1

This afternoon, the House will vote on the HIRE Vets Act, which provides for an innovative way to encourage hiring of veterans. The legislation would require the Department of Labor to establish the “HIRE Vets Medallion Program” to annually recognize private and public sector businesses for their efforts to employ veterans. DOL would make awards to employers, on a voluntary basis, who recruit, employ, and retain veterans; and provide community and charitable services supporting the veteran community. Employers would earn either platinum or gold status based on requirements related to the number of veterans hired each year, if they provide pay equity for Guardsmen and Reserve employees who were called up to active military service, and if certain other requirements are met. You can read more about the bill here: https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/244

In Central Washington, we understand the vital importance of water infrastructure. I recently introduced legislation in Congress to streamline water storage and infrastructure projects that will help communities - especially in the arid West - to plan for the future. The growth of our communities and our ability to confront frequent drought depend on access to new water resources, so the framework for developing these projects should not be bogged down by delayed permits and endless reviews. H.R. 875, the Bureau of Reclamation Water Project Streamlining Act, would apply the same streamlined water project development process used by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers under the Water Resources Reform Development Act of 2014 to the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation in order to facilitate the construction of new dams and reservoirs. You can read the legislation here: https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/875

Good evening Central Washington! I'm on my way to hear President Trump give his first Joint Address to Congress. I'm looking forward to hearing a positive vision focused on creating jobs, growing our economy, and securing our homeland. All Americans deserve opportunity and freedom to pursue happiness. I stand ready to work with the President and my colleagues in Congress to strengthen our commitment to America's founding ideals and achieve a safer, more prosperous Union.
My guests from Central Washington to tonight's Joint Address are Washington Farm Bureau's Mike LaPlant and Mike Montaney (pictured) of American Legion Post 28 in Ephrata.

My response to President Trump’s first Joint Address to Congress:  America must be strong and true to our values. No American should feel forgotten or left out of the promise to pursue happiness. Tonight, I was heartened by an optimistic and unifying message that the President is working to restore limited government, improve economic opportunity, and ensure the safety of all Americans. He honored our fallen heroes, like Ryan Owens, whose sacrifice will never be forgotten.  There is much work to do. We must rescue Americans from the consequences of the failures of Obamacare by restoring access to quality, affordable health insurance options. Reversing job-killing regulations and delivering on tax reform will help spur economic growth and create opportunity for families. Just today, the President signed an order to review the intrusive and overreaching Waters of the United States rule, which is great news for our agriculture community. Improving our nation’s infrastructure must prioritize critical water storage projects in the West and in Washington state, such as the Yakima River Basin Water Enhancement Project. And securing our borders by enforcing immigration laws must be met with efforts to reform our immigration system. On all of these issues and more, I look forward to working with the President to restore a ‘can-do’ spirit in America.

Today, I spoke on a conference call with a group of Yakima pediatric dentists who informed me of a major technical issue under the Affordable Care Act that prevents parents from accessing dental services for their children. Many pediatric dentists have been reporting problems with families not realizing their medical plans with dental coverage contained deductibles as high as $5,000. Pediatric oral health care is vital to prevent further ramifications down the road for our children’s health. This is one more reason I am committed to reforming our broken health care system and providing relief for families in Washington. While Congress debates the American Health Care Act and budgetary components of health care reform, I look forward to also supporting further legislation to fix broken programs that preclude children from receiving the care they need.

All Americans deserve access to quality, affordable health care. Obamacare is not working, and we must act to improve our health care system. I have heard countless stories from Washingtonians whose coverage has not translated to affordable care. Many families are struggling with rising premiums and deductibles. We must transition to a better health care system that puts patients first, not higher taxes and more government mandates. We must strengthen the safety net for the most vulnerable while providing more choices that allow Americans to access the insurance options that they—not the government—want to purchase. I am disappointed that we have reached a delay in moving forward on solutions, but I will continue to work to support healthcare proposals that put individuals first, not the government bureaucracy.

Today I wrote to express my firm opposition to the North Cascades Ecosystem Grizzly Bear Restoration Plan. I am concerned that the National Park Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service are moving forward with plans for the restoration and reintroduction of grizzly bears to the North Cascades Ecosystem, without the use of sound science to support such a movement. I believe such decisions should be made with substantial local input and support from the local communities that will be most impacted by the proposed Grizzly Bear Restoration Plan. Based off of numerous conversations my office has had with local community members and elected officials, it has come to light that NPS and FWS are repeating past mistakes by failing to provide for adequate public input in the Public Comment process. You can read the letter here: https://newhouse.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/newhouse-voices-opposition-north-cascades-ecosystem-grizzly-bear. You can post your own comments on the draft EIS here: https://parkplanning.nps.gov/document.cfm?parkID=327&projectID=44144&documentID=77025

Their stories of paying higher prices for insurance and higher deductibles with limited insurance options have been the reason I have voted in the past to repeal Obamacare along with its mandate and bureaucratic regulations. I strongly believe that every American deserves access to affordable health care, and the status quo under the ACA is not working. Because of my wife Carol’s health, I have largely remained by her side and was unable to be in D.C. for the vote on the AHCA. I will continue to work with my colleagues to keep my promise to reverse the burdens created by Obamacare and restore patient-centered health care.

Our nation is facing an epidemic. Over the past two decades, opioid overdoses have quadrupled in the United States. Washington has faced significant increases in drug overdose death rates, including a 70% increase in synthetic opioid overdose deaths in just the past ten years. It is clear this is a real crisis, which is why Congress is committed to combating this growing epidemic.  Late last year, Congress passed sweeping legislation called the “21st Century Cures Act,” bipartisan legislation that authorized $6.3 billion in funding to bring our health care innovation infrastructure into the 21st Century. This legislation included $1 billion for opioid prevention and treatment programs throughout all 50 states over two years. Earlier this spring, the federal government began awarding grants to the states in order to confront the opioid crisis, including $11.7 million to Washington state.   While these funds will help expand treatment options, there is still much more work to be done at the federal level, which is why I cosponsored legislation like H.R. 1057, the “Synthetics Trafficking and Overdose Prevention, or “STOP” Act. Designed to stop dangerous synthetic drugs like fentanyl and carfentanil from being shipped through our borders, this legislation will combat bad actors in China and India who have been taking advantage of weaknesses in international mail security standards to break U.S. customs laws and wreak havoc on our communities.

This year alone, over eight million acres have burned across our country, and another 80 million are considered high risk to the threat of catastrophic wildfires. Central Washington has been devastated by wildfires in recent years. From the Carlton Complex fire in 2014, which was the largest in state history, to the Okanogan Complex fire which only surpassed that record the following year, to losing three firefighters in 2015—our communities know what it means to live with the overwhelming consequences of continual disastrous wildfires, year after year. It doesn’t have to be this way. We can solve this problem. These fires amount to a national disaster, and if we do not acknowledge them as such, then they will only continue to devastate rural communities across the nation. I joined my colleagues, including Congressman Bruce Westerman, to give voice to our communities and constituents to offer solutions. The Wildfire Disaster Funding Act and the Resilient Federal Forests Act are part of the answer to addressing the broken funding systems and lack of resources necessary to adequately prevent and suppress wildfires.

I was proud to support the CHAMPIONING HEALTHY KIDS Act, which passed today in the House of Representatives. This important bill includes funding for several of Central Washington's health priorities. First, it funds the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). CHIP provides health care to lower-income children, and this bill would extend the funding for five years. Second, the bill extends funding for the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF) for two additional years. This funding is used at federally qualified health centers, which provide an array of comprehensive health services to medically-underserved populations. Community health centers serve over 280,000 constituents in Washington's 4th District every year. Lastly, this bill provides funding for Teaching Health Centers, so we can continue to train primary care doctors and retain them at community-based clinics in rural areas. With three Teaching Health Centers in Central Washington, this funding is important to ensure that we have qualified, well-educated doctors providing care for families in less-populated areas.

I was proud to cast my vote today for historic tax reform that provides a simpler and fairer system for families and businesses in Central Washington. This reform flattens rates and lifts burdens from taxpayers, and it unleashes American businesses, large and small, to better compete. About eighty percent of filers in the Fourth District use the standard deduction, so doubling it will provide real tax relief for the majority of families. Reform will boost manufacturers by allowing small businesses and farmers to immediately write off the full cost of new equipment. Reform will repeal the unfair death tax, which hinders family farms and small businesses from passing on the success of a lifetime of hard work on to the next generation. As this process continues, I look forward to working with my colleagues in the Senate to send legislation to President Trump for his signature. https://newhouse.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/real-tax-relief-families

Water is vital for the livelihoods and the prosperity of the western United States, and communities in Central Washington know all too well the detrimental impacts of facing severe droughts and water shortages. I was proud to introduce H.R. 4419, the Bureau of Reclamation and Bureau of Indian Affairs Water Project Streamlining Act, which aims to apply the same streamlined water project development process for BOR and BIA that was established in 2014 for the Army Corps of Engineers. This legislation would also authorize several key water development projects, including the third phase of a vital effort in Central Washington, the Yakima River Basin Water Enhancement Project. The Yakima River Basin Plan is an excellent example of collaboration that offers a solution for water users, giving them more certainty and recognizing the concerns of conservationists and several other stakeholders in the region. For his significant contributions to the safety of constituents in the 4th District, I spoke on the House floor to congratulate Sheriff Harvey Gjesdal of Douglas County on his recently announced retirement. Sheriff Gjesdal has served in Washington State law enforcement for over 30 years. He began his career in 1985 at the Garfield County Sheriff’s Office, and he spent eight years in the Bellevue Police Department before landing in Douglas County in 1995. He was promoted to sergeant in 2000 and elected to his current position in 2006. Additionally, he served in the U.S. Coast Guard Reserve for 26 years where he was activated four times, including two tours in the Middle East. For the last 22 years, Sheriff Gjesdal has been promoting safety and building strong relationships in Central Washington. I am thankful for his leadership and compassion, and I urge my colleagues to join me in congratulating him on a successful career.
